results.title: Japan: the bamboo bends and does not break
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, ABC and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”.
Provides insight into the historical and cultural background of Japan, drawing attention to the sense of duty and obligation held by the Japanese in ways that are different from people in the West. Photography by Dean Semler. Unit Manager: Damien Parer.

results.title: That's Democracy
results.brief_description: A seven part program designed to provide an overview of our electoral system and its development. Commencing with an outline of the principles of democracy, the programs proceed to trace the history of Government in Australia, discuss the different levels of Government and examine the role of political parties, the voting system, the conduct of elections and the use of the referendum in changing the Constitution.

results.title: That's dancing!
results.creator_credit: Jack Haley, David Niven Jr and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A collection of fifty famous dancers from the world of film, ballet and Broadway are presented in musical sequences ranging from the romantic ballroom dances of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers to the electrifying streetgate ballet of “West Side Story”. Highlights the classical brillance of Mikhail Baryshnikov and performances by Busby Berkeley and Michael Jackson.

results.title: Thanks girls and goodbye
results.creator_credit: Sue Hardistry, Sue Maslin and Newground Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary about a group of women who worked on farms during the World War II in Australia - “the land girls”. Officially established by the Australian Government in 1942, the Australian Women’s Land Army was set up to help fill the shortage of manpower on farms. Their story is symbolic of a far greater number of women who participated in the vital war activity of food production.

results.title: Indonesia
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, ABC, Film Australia and University of Queensland Press
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”.
What makes this diverse chain of islands into a nation? Indonesia’s national motto “Unity in diversity” is the film’s starting point in its concentration on Sumatra, Java and Bali - the most populated areas. One of the most interesting sequences is an examination of the Indonesian concept of power - that there is a finite amount of it in the world. Another highlight is the Indonesian Army and its role as an essential ingredient in society - not, as so often in the West, as something appended to, or imposed on, society.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, ABC, Film Australia and University of Queensland Press

results.title: Thanks for the ride
results.creator_credit: John Kent Harrison, John Kramer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This finely crafted drama, set in Ontario’s cottage country, revolves around two teenaged boys from the city who pick up two local girls on a Saturday night and take them for a ride. Based on an Alice Munro short story, Thanks for the Ride is about values and morals, expectations and broken dreams, class differences and peer pressure. It is also about the overwhelming intensity of adolescent emotions and that momentous event—the first sexual encounter. An excellent film for use in family life, values education, Canadian literature, and creative writing courses.

results.title: Thailand
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Don Murray, John Temple, Roan Hannam, ABC, Film Australia and University of Queensland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”
A look at the historical and cultural background of Thailand. Focuses on the respect the Thais have for the monks and their religion, and the veneration of the monarchy.

results.title: Hong Kong, Singapore: fragrant harbour, lion city
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Temple, ABC, Film Australia and Queensland University of Technology
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”.
A look at the cultural background of Hong Kong and Singapore. Both places are governed by the professional elite ruling class. However, they have produced very different societies under the pressure of history and circumstances. Sujitable for upper secondary level.
